Hi Joseph,

> Well, but even with NEAT the concept of layers
> exists. In a non-recurrant
> network you can define it by the length of the
> shortest path from an input
> to neuron to whatever neuron you're classifying. 

Yes, that's true.

> Basically what I'm asking is when you
> add a new neuron, where
> do you put it? Does it go on the same line as the
> neuron being mutated or
> does it make a parallel line. 

I haven't thought it through all that explicitly, but
my first thought was that subnets, or modules, would
only work with particular numbers of inputs and
outputs. 

For example, a subnet like this:

(X) (X)
  \ /
  (X)

could only replace a neuron with a minimum of one
incoming connection and two outgoing connections, so
it could replace (A) in the following network, but not
(B):


(O) (O) (O)
  \ /    |
  (A)   (B)
    \   /
     \ /
     (I)
 
Basically, a subnet would be associated with a
particular number of incoming and outgoing connections
(be they recurrent or forward), and could only mutate
to replace a single neuron that also had that same
number of incoming and outgoing connections.  Does
this make sense?

I was thinking that by only replacing a single node,
this would mitigate the impact of the initial
mutation, in line with the general philosophy of NEAT.

Derek
